ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Coding, statistics, Quantitative research desidn, data visualization, statistical theory.

In this course I learned the basics of doing statistical analysis in R through trial and error / working on the problem sets. We also reviewed what kind of statistical analysis should be done in sociology/social science analyses and how to do them.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Explanation of statistics in lecture, Assignment design, course layout (p-sets were well spaced).

Weaknesses: Reliant on attendance of the optional discussion sections to not fall behind. Alert students to not schedule conflicts with discussion section during registration.

Daniel and Ryan were great! Super efficient communication and thorough explanations. The class was based on lecture slides, which aren't too exciting. But, the Daniel's interactive questions, problem-sets, and open-ended midterm and final projects were all super engaging. This is not a course that is going to teach you how to code in R. Daniel and Ryan were both super helpful when it came to coding questions in office hours or via email, but you'll have to learn it on your own. However, the coding tasks were never impossible. 

My only issue was that, towards the end of the course, we were slightly off schedule and had to push deadlines closer together. The only problem with this was that, given all my other final assignments, I couldn't explore my final project in depth. 

But overall, a great course that combines statistics with real world application!

A strength of the course is that because the problem sets are done in R, I definitely left the course with working knowledge of how to do something in R in the future, and how to go about doing something I don't know how to do. However, there were a lot of learning pains throughout the course because the lectures focus heavily on the stats content rather than R (though the code is available in the slides / there is some explanation). Because of that, I think the structure of the course is both a strength and a weakness.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are looking to learn how to do basic coding and statistics in Sociology, this course is a must take.

Yes, if you're looking for a QR credit this is a manageable one especially if you've used R before or have taken high school statistics. There's a lot of information thrown at you, but Daniel and Ryan were very understanding, so don't be afraid to ask questions.
